[GRAMMAR]: Subject-verb agreement error ("If Russia have not sacrifice")
[SPELLING]: Typo in chapter title ("Won" instead of "Win")
[SYNTAX]: Missing preposition in quoted text ("deprived the enemy of the opportunity")
Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., long convoluted sentences with multiple clauses).
[LEXICON]: Minor awkward phrasing (e.g., "It may was easily seen").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift between critiquing Ludendorff and reiterating Russia’s role.
[REPEAT]: Mild redundancy in emphasizing Russia’s strategic impact.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentences disrupting flow.
[LEXICON]: Repetitive phrasing (e.g., repeated references to Ludendorff’s memoirs without variation).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between paragraphs (e.g., from Warsaw to broader impact).
[CLARITY]: Forced analogy (Mexican example) without clear integration.

[STRUCTURE]: Repetitive emphasis on Russia’s diversion of German forces without clear transitions.
[CLARITY]: Assumes historical context (e.g., Ludendorff’s role, specific battles) without explanation.

[GRAMMAR]: Subject-verb agreement error ("have" instead of "had" in "the Russian Army again have to offer").
Missing verb conjugation ("could not therefore carried" instead of "carry").
[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in long, complex sentences (e.g., "It is natural that in 1915...").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between paragraphs (e.g., from Brusilov’s offensive to Verdun without explicit connection).
[STRUCTURE]: Assumed contextual knowledge of historical events without clear links.
Awkward transitions (e.g., "These figures are rather minimized...").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between numbered conclusions (e.g., points 5 → 6).
[STRUCTURE]: Sudden transition to "Conclusion" without clear recap.

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb tense ("We have see" instead of "We have seen").
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally overly complex sentence structures (e.g., lengthy clauses about mobilization logistics).
[LEXICON]: Awkward phrasing ("one-seventh, a sixth, or fifth part").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from historical analysis (1918 peace conference) to speculative geopolitical future without clear connectors.
[REPETITION]: Rhetorical question ("Where will Russia be then?") repeated without strong narrative justification.
